Dont say cassiopeia is just weak; it clouds up the discussion. The problem is that atm cassiopeia is badly designed, not weak. Late game and in some cases even mid game, cassio can melt faces. 

Before the rework **all she really needed were QoL fixes: Move while casting, E reset mechanic, R bugginess and her auto-attack** . Her passive was lame and only served to justify high mana costs, but at least it didnt work against her basic play patterns.
I cant emphasize enough how 90% of her problems was clunkiness because she was so old; lets compare to Syndra who has complicated mechanics, but still feels really smooth and responsive:

Move while casting, very clear and fast AAÃ­ng (underestimated),  no delay on Q, very responsve (immediate) R, passive that doesn't restrain her.

Bad basic gameplay design is the problem with the rework, which should've been picked up on in basic PBE testing. There have to be trade-offs; ways to shut her down and consequences if you fail to do so. (Let nasus farm = problem late, let Fizz roam = watch out for ganks etc.)

If you leave cass alone = you win (no stacks, she cant push in and she cant roam).
If you put Cass under pressure you win (she cant waveclear, forced to use spells on minions and not you = no stacks),.
if you fight her you win (because she's weak).
if you both die, you win (She has bad ratios, if you want her to be an APC, give her scaling like ADC's)

Nobody's saying "omfg dont let Cass free farm!" nobody is saying "Wtf dont feed Cass!" nobody is saying "watch out for Cassio Roams, shes 6!"

new skarner is stronger than old skarner, and is actually in a good place, though the meta is a bit toxic for him right this second.

I second this opinion.

I like the old Skarner, and loved him more than ever after his reworks. There is no question that Skarner is so much better than before.

I don't second this opinion. I loved the old Skarner. New one is ok, and definitely a bit stronger, but he's just so boring. The new E is a strong contender for the most boring spell in the game, and he's still got frustrations like ihs terrible mana costs that leave you oom after one fight, or the stun just being a glorified channel interrupt before level 11. I don't like how his invading and dueling potential went down either. He may be stronger, but there's just nothing really interesting about him.

Also, it's not a matter of "the meta is a bit toxic for him". He's fucked by mobility and long ranged cc, and those have never gone out of meta. It never will either. Old Skarner actually dealt with that better because he could at least lock someone down if he caught up to them or if they had to go through him. New one doesn't do that nearly so well. He's not going to magically come back into the meta some day unless the game undergoes massive changes. Certainly season 5 isn't going to be it, what with all the health items being added and the change of jungle items to focus on stats he doesn't need.

His new E is not really boring. It's your standard slowing skillshot. You can't even argue that it's worse than his old E because you didn't even level up his old E until you maxed out your other two abilities.

In terms of dealing with mobility, old Skarner had a really hard time getting to his targets. New Skarner made that so much easier because instead of having only one chance to jump on your target, you now have two. Skarner's Fracture gives him another potential initiation tool that he did not have before, and that increases his reliability.

The difference between Old Skarner and New Skarner is reliability: Old Skarner was incredibly feast or famine, while the new one doesn't snowball too hard, but doesn't fall behind nearly as hard as the old one did.

It is the standard slowing skillshot. In fact, it's the very basic, uninteresting, generic as hell standard skillshot that almost no one actually has because they can all get nicer mechanics. Almost every other slowing skillshot either has a more interesting mechanic, or it serves a much more useful role in the champion's kit (like Karma's standard slowing skillshot doing actual damage as a poke mechanism). The new E is a narrow, slow, skillshot that only slows, and it is a high duration but a low uptime.  The only thing it has going for it is sheer numbers. That's not valuable to me. Getting close is more gated by my sustained mobility, particularly since the E is very easy to dodge. Yeah, it's technically better than the old E, but that means absolutely nothing because I don't compare it to his old E, I compare it to his old slow. The old slow was interesting to use, and this one isn't (and no, I'm not saying permaslow has to come back. That's a different argument altogether). Besides, I liked being able to max out on utility by level 12 and then scale purely in terms of damage and tankiness. There was nothing wrong with that paradigm. I didn't care about not taking E early.

I never found myself needing another initiation tool on old Skarner. The main issue was whether or not the enemies had mobility skills and if I can exploit anngles of attack. If I got in, I was highly rewarded. I preferred that. Now, I'm not rewarded nearly as much. That's boring.

To make this clear: I think Skarner is a crappy initiator. He was before, and he is now. He has a potential for a really good ult initiation, but the actual cases where it is highly effective are low. I never used to play him as an initiator, and I still don't now. Because of that, I don't value the new E as an initiation tool, because the assumptions of the enemy not using CC on you, not using mobility to get away, and not just hurting you until you stop all have to still be met. When I do initiate, it's much more often with a flash than with the E, and it's on timeframes where even stopping to cast the E could let them use escape skills.

The reliability difference is overstated. The old one could always turn into a peel-bot with tanky items if behind. The new one does that job just about as well. You're more likely to be ok instead of slightly behind as the new Skarner than the old one, but you're just as likely to be so far behind you're useless.

To me, Skarner is just the generic autoattacking bruiser archetype right now. Nothing really special outside of the ult, and that can't carry the entire kit. The old Skarner had a zone of extreme threat thing going on with the permaslow and resetting cooldowns, and he had highly positioning-rewarding gameplay. Those were fun. The only thing I really find more fun about new Skarner is that I'm stronger than on the old Skarner. It's fun because it's easier to win. Not really because of anything else. That's my problem with the kit. All of the new elements are boring.

Really, if you like him, more power to you and don't let me spoil your fun, but I mark him as a rework that failed to meet my expectations. I played with the new kit and had about as much fun with it as I had with Yorick. It's just dull. It's also worth nothing that since he's the fifth lowest played champion despite being objectively stronger than the old third least played Skarner (which for a major rework is a lack of popularity growth matched only by Cassiopeia's, and she's just weak), this isn't exactly a rework that many people are enjoying.

I'd be happy to see him get another rework in the future. Then he can be the only champion with more reworks than skins.

Haha, perhaps that is the reason! Maybe seeing me on Cassio puts them on tilt so to speak. I know I get scared when I'm against a one trick pony on their main. 

However, on another note, and something that a lot of people are ignoring, is the fact that the new Cassiopeia does more single target damage at almost every point in the game than old Cassio regardless of her AP because of the Twin Fang resetting on cast. 

You can have 60 AP with the new Cass, and as long as you have your Tear or Catalyst and are maxing Twin Fang, you trade better than old Cass did because even though her ratios are lower, you get out considerably more Twin Fangs. 

The only thing the new Cassio sucks at that the old Cass decent at is being able to max Q and poke. If you try to max Q, then your Twin Fangs won't be doing full damage until level 13 I believe. You basically HAVE to max Twin Fangs. If you don't then you will not be relevant until they are actually maxed.


I've said it before, but I'll say it again. All the rework needs is an adjustment to the stack milestones. For a lot of people it is difficult to space properly (which is huge now on Cass because you get max DPS at full range unlike before) and take advantage of that to get easy stacks against the enemy laner. Making the last reward a bit easier to obtain will do a lot I think.

I believe you will hit a wall and when that happens you'll be handicapping yourself by playing Cass. Like myself with Diana. I was able to stomp with it until Gold with my current knowledge/skill but when I reached higher Gold it became impossible. It may not be the best example comparing such vastly different ranks but I think it's a fairly accurate comparison.

Just to throw it out there, according to op.gg, the last 7 days of Cass games in NA Diamond have totaled to a 42.65% win rate with a 2.03 average ratio. It has not improved, that's close to the lowest in the game. These statistics are mostly from people who know Cass inside in out, mostly those who main her, and it's still 42%. That makes it inflated, if it was played as normally as other champions the win rate would be back in 30s again.

In regards to your comparison to you and Diana, no I don't think that's the case at all. Champions that are only effective against weaker opponents skill-wise are the only champions that would cause you to hit a wall like you describe. Cassiopeia (and Diana as well) do not fit that category. I would argue that Mordekaiser and Miss Fortune would fit that ticket though.  I think as long as I play my best I will continue to climb until I reach the point where I'm playing against people that are simply better than me regardless of champion. I don't think my choice in Cassiopeia will inhibit my potential at all. She isn't a champion that relies on cheese or uneducated opponents to excel. If she did then I would agree with you that there would eventually be a point where my opponents are simply too good at the game to basically trick them/use their poor play to win.

And no, I don't think that data is coming from Cass mains in Diamond because I know most of the high elo Cass mains and the only ones playing her non-stop are me and couple of other people. All of us are having pretty decent success with her. I would argue that most of those games are from people trying to figure her out and failing at it. She isn't an easy champion. Certain not one you can pick up in a few days.

Perhaps the only reason I'm having so much success on Cass right now is simply because of the amount of games I have on her and people respecting my capabilities with her.

My point is that she's REALLY close to being balanced and she doesn't need a huge fix to make her viable. A few small tweaks to make her late game easier to reach is all that she needs from a balance standpoint.

From the thematic standpoint, maybe there could be more work done, sure. For me, this isn't a huge deal, but I can totally understand how it is for others. 

TL;DR: Balance wise, Cass only needs minor tweaks to help her late game become more accessible. Thematic wise, there may be some more work to be done.

So I took a break from this for a bit but here is my 2 cents after giving Cassio some more testing since then.

Like many of you I HATED this rework when it first launched with a passion, I believe some of my earlier posts referred to it as "a weak abomination," and I really felt that way.  Q did pitiful damaged compared to old cass and I was getting out dueled by champs like Orianna and a freaking Veigar in the early game.  

Then I took some of King Cobra's advice and tried her E max and going tear or Catalyst first and focus on positioning to get the max amount of Es in on each Q/W I landed.  Since then I've actually had a good deal of success with her, listening to a diamond about a champ they spam leads to good things happening who knew?  Joking aside she isn't as terrible as I first thought, she still can't poke worth a flip and doesn't retain the poison feel of old cass, which is something I would love to see addressed, but I can't say she is anywhere near as crippled as I first thought.  For me, at least, it's been an odd play style change that does required a lot of getting used to.  

Note these are not games in which I just stomped out the game to be able to be successful, in my last game laning against Xerith, for example, I actually went 0/2 in lane and still managed to come back and we ended up winning that game in a 4v5 at the end when our Gnar kept DCing, and twitch got several lessons about why coming out of stealth on a Cassio is a terrible idea.

She does still melt people, and she does still deal a lot of damage, it's just all focused now on 1 target instead of being able to AoE melt an entire team from a pretty strong distance and while that play style may of been fun the more I get stuck against long range harassment champs that I have little to no ability to interact with the more I realize that the old Q max play style for Cass was really miserable for anyone who had to play against it.

I agree with basically everything you said (ive had some fun experiences vs a twitch too XD), but there are flaws in this new way she needs to be played.

Q/W ing then E ing a few times is the way to play her, but early game Ive found that people that decide to just disrespect me and trade with me always come on top. The only way to get  Q/W + E harass to work is if the opponont thinks you're the old cass and is scared to trade. The damage is too low for the damage you get vs ANY champ pre 6.

Her passive also requires interaction, ranged harass doesn't just hurt her like it hurts any other champion, it also prevents her from stacking up, You cant say "Im going to focus on farm to get my stacks up", you need the stackig through farm AND the E on champions to stack fast enough.

Then there's the obvious one: average game length, Cassiopeia is mathematically set-up to lose more games than she wins because of the delayed scaling from her passive. So if you play her wrong and try to get ahead early, you lose and if you play her right and go for late, you still lose (maybe with a slightly better feeling, right now im feeling im losing better with cassio :) )

Her passive is incredibly stupid. I mean stupid...stupid. While yes it does have a free death cap, it takes forever to get it, and then the power spike it far too pronounced. I say we do this with the stacking since we know that they aren't going to get rid of it:

**Passive: ***Increasing Potency* (Name Change)

*As Cassiopeia damages champions her poisons become more and more potent, providing stacks that increase her lethality. She gains one stack for poisoning a champion per second. Cassiopeia does not gain stacks from poisoning multiple champions. Upon reaching the stack limit, Cassiopeia becomes more deadly, gaining increased Ability Power, Cooldown Reduction, True damage, and Spell Penetration.*

**50 Stacks:** 5% Additional Ability Power, 5% Cooldown Reduction.
**75 Stacks:** Cassiopeia's Twin Fang now heals for 6/8/10/12/14/16 (+10% AP) at levels 1/4/7/10/13/16.
**100 Stacks:** 5% Additional Ability Power (10% Total)
**125  Stacks:** 10% Cooldown Reduction (15% Total)
**150 Stacks:** Casting Twin Fang on Poisoned Targets now deals an addition 5/7/9/11/13/15 (+.05% AP) true damage at levels 1/4/7/10/13/16. 
**200 Stacks:** 5% Additional Ability Power (15% Total), 5% Addtional Cooldown reduction (20% Total).
**250 Stacks:** 5% Addtional Ability Power (20% Total), 5% Additional Cooldown Reduction (25% Total).
**300 Stacks:** 10% Spell Penetration.


So at 300 Stacks it would look like this: 25% CDR, 20% AP, True Damage, 10% Spell Penetration.

By removing the ability to gain stacks by last hitting minions with Twin Fang it encourages Cassioepia to constantly harass her opponent in order to increase her power. Doing this also allows us to cut the maximum stacks from 400 to 300, which will more likely reach a 25 minute power spike versus a 35 minute power spike. Adding True Damage (albiet at a low ratio) makes her Twin Fang more satisfying to use in the mid game, and although its not a lot of true damage, every little bit helps. By removing 10% additional ability power, it allows us to add spell penetration instead, afterall nothing helps a late game mage melt tanks like Penetration. This also makes her feel a little bit more powerful. Yes, seeing 900 something AP seems cool, but why not have 850 AP and dish out more damage?

Overall I think these changes will do a world of good for Cassiopeia by not only providing a little bit more early game damage for her harass, but it makes stacking a much more achievable goal by providing more milestones that are easier to reach. The QoL buff to her ultimate will increase her feel and make her less wonky to use. Adding a little base damage to W makes it a little easier to wave clear, and actually provides an incentive for a champion to not just stand in it.
